messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Genes are small parts in our body. They tell our body how to work.  
A mutation is when a gene changes.  

People ask about genes and our brains. They ask about talking.  
Did gene changes give us the ability to talk?  

People who study genes found a gene mutation long ago.  
It was 200,000 to 100,000 years ago.  
This change helps us talk and move our mouth and face.  

Monkeys have a gene like ours.  
But their gene did not change.  

We do not know how much genes help us talk.  
Maybe one day we know how genes help us talk.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5957 is well below the required 0.75. The core message about the nuanced link between genetics and language development is lost. For example, the writer says “This change helps us talk” instead of “a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face,” removing the research uncertainty and mechanistic detail. FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8666 is below the required 0.90. Key terms like genetics, language development, and DNA are missing. Suggestion: Reintroduce the term genetics, mention language development, include DNA, and restore the idea of research uncertainty and connection rather than simple causation.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Genes are small parts in our body. They tell our body how to work. A mutation is a change in a gene. Genetics is the study of genes.

People who study genes ask about genetics and language development. Did gene changes give us the ability to speak?

They found a gene mutation. It was 200,000 to 100,000 years ago. It may have a connection with speaking. It may help our brain control our mouth and face. This is not certain yet.

Monkeys have a similar gene. But their gene did not change.

We do not know how much genetics help language development. Maybe one day we find answers in our DNA.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.706 is below the required 0.75. This shows the core message is weakened by adding broad definitions like “Genes are small parts in our body” and splitting the focus on research questions about genetics and language development.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Genes are parts in our body.  
A mutation is a change in a gene.  

Scientists study genes and language.  
They ask: Did gene changes give humans speech?  
Scientists found a mutation.  
It happened 200,000 to 100,000 years ago.  
It helps people speak.  
It helps the brain control our mouth and face.  
Monkeys also have this gene.  
But their gene did not change.  
We do not yet know how much genes help language.  
Maybe one day we find answers in our DNA.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Scientists study the influence of genetics on brain and language development.
Genes are parts of our body.
A mutation is a change in a gene.
They ask: Did changes in genes give humans speech?
Scientists found a mutation.
It happened 200,000 to 100,000 years ago.
It seems to help people speak.
It helps the brain control our mouth and face.
Monkeys have the same gene.
It did not change in monkeys.
We do not yet know the influence of genetics on language.
Maybe one day we find answers in our DNA.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

Scientists study the effect of our genes on language development.

These questions are about how our brain and language change.  
Genes are parts in our body.  
A mutation is a change in a gene.  
Researchers have found a gene mutation 200,000 to 100,000 years ago.  
This gene mutation helps speaking and brain control of mouth and face.  
Monkeys have a similar gene but no gene mutation.  
It is too early to know the effect of genes on language.  
Maybe one day we find answers in our DNA.

2. The term 'genetics' is a B2 term and was not defined in simple A2 vocabulary
3. The acronym 'DNA' is not defined and assumes specialist knowledge above A2

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: There are more questions when we look at the study of genes.  
These questions are about how our brain and our language change.  
Genes are parts of our body that tell us what to do.  
A mutation is a change in a gene.  
Researchers found a mutation in our genes.  
The change happened from 200,000 years ago to 100,000 years ago.  
This mutation may help us speak.  
It may help us move our face and mouth.  
Monkeys have the same genes, but they have no mutation.  
It is too early to know how genes affect our language.  
Maybe one day we find answers in the code in our cells.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8805 is below the required 0.90.
- The term “genetics” was replaced with “study of genes,” losing the precise scientific word from the original.
- The word “DNA” was changed to “code in our cells,” diluting the core lexical reference.
Suggestion: Restore the original key terms “genetics” and “DNA” to maintain fidelity with the source text.

Researchers found a mutation between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago.  
This mutation may help us speak.

Monkeys have the same genes, but they have no mutation.  
It is too early to know how genetics affects our language.  
Maybe one day we find answers in our DNA.

They tell our body what to do.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Deep Qualitative Audit Failure. The text passes factual, meaning, and CEFR classifier checks but breaks A2 vocabulary and structure rules.
- Vocabulary Audit: uses B2-level words gene and mutation; B1-level word connection; non-A2 words monkeys, speaking, DNA, which.
- Structural Analysis: contains a long sentence with a relative clause starting with which; uses complex grammar instead of only and, but, so, because.
Suggestion: Replace gene/mutation/connection with simpler terms like part/change/link. Remove which-clauses by splitting into two sentences. Avoid uncommon words like monkeys, DNA, speaking; use simpler synonyms. Ensure all sentences use only and, but, so, or because as connectors.
